pbcoreIdentifier.identifier: Division of Broadcasting Sound Recordings, Record Series 13/6/5, Tape 040

pbcoreTitle.title: My Experience in the Labor and Radical Struggles of the Thirties, by A.J. Muste, February 9, 1966

pbcoreSubject.subject: Workers' Party of the United States
Workers Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Workers Rights" Categories

pbcoreDescription.description: On the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, A.J. Muste, a social justice activist, describes the development of labor unions during the Great Depression. Muste became an avowed Marxist-Leninist, and he was instrumental in forming the American Workers Party. However, Muste says he began to question the ability of Marxism in carrying out efforts to help workers. “I was convinced that the concentration on political maneuvering,” he explains. “Would virtually eliminate our effectiveness in the mass struggle taking place in basic industries.”
Good clear sound with slight podium and crowd noise. Ends abruptly.

pbcoreTitle.title: The Supreme Court and Public Education, with James E. Allen, Jr., March 7, 1966

pbcoreSubject.subject: African American Civil Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "African American Civil Rights" Categories

pbcoreSubject.subject: Court Rulings
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Court Rulings" Categories

pbcoreSubject.subject: Equal Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Equal Rights" Categories

pbcoreSubject.subject: School Desegregation
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "School Desegregation" Categories

pbcoreDescription.description: On the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, James E. Allen, Jr., New York State Commissioner of Education, says there has been an uptick in public education cases dealing with civil rights and liberties going to the U.S. Supreme Court. The most difficult problem facing education is the issue of race relations, and he says the ultimate goal for the nation’s schools should be a truly integrated educational system. While past court rulings, like Brown v. Board of Education, have helped states deal with the problems of education, Allen says the court should start focusing its attention on helping communities avoid de facto segregation.
Starts abruptly without intro. Sound becomes very slightly muffled at times, still very good.

pbcoreTitle.title: The American Negro: His Self-Image and Integration, by Alvin F. Poussaint, October 7, 1966

pbcoreSubject.subject: African American Civil Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "African American Civil Rights" Categories

pbcoreSubject.subject: White Resistance
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "White Resistance" Categories

pbcoreSubject.subject: Civil Unrest
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Civil Unrest" Categories

pbcoreSubject.subject: Equal Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Equal Rights" Categories

pbcoreSubject.subject: Mass Protest
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Mass Protest" Categories

pbcoreSubject.subject: School Desegregation
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "School Desegregation" Categories

pbcoreDescription.description: Alvin F. Poussaint, a professor of psychiatry at Tufts University, speaks at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign about how racism has damaged African Americans’ self-image. Poussaint argues “the Negro has come to form his self image and self concept on the basis on primarily what white racists have prescribed for him.” He adds that in some cases, black people hate other blacks more than their white oppressors. Black consciousness efforts, like the civil rights movement, appear to raise the self-image of African Americans, but Poussaint argues integration does not offer “the mass of Negros a solution to the problems of negative self concept.”

pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Civil Unrest" Categories

pbcoreDescription.description: The Rev. Arthur M. Brazier, president of the Woodlawn Organization, delivers a speech at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign about the widening social gap between black and white people. Brazier says citizen participation is essential in any democracy, and he says he would like to see more self-determination among black communities. He says non-violent power organizations must be established to stimulate housing, jobs and education.

pbcoreIdentifier.identifier: Division of Broadcasting Sound Recordings, Record Series 13/6/5, Tape 101

pbcoreTitle.title: The University and the Self-Determination of Afro-Americans, with Donald H. Smith, February 23, 1968

pbcoreSubject.subject: African American Civil Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "African American Civil Rights" Categories

pbcoreSubject.subject: Student Movement
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Student Movement" Categories

pbcoreSubject.subject: Equal Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Equal Rights" Categories

pbcoreDescription.description: Donald H. Smith, former chairman of Baruch College’s Black and Latino Faculty Association, says there is a widespread crisis in higher education. At a speech on the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Smith says most college campuses are not responsive to the needs of black students. As a former student at the U of I, Smith says racism on the campus was “so dehumanizing and so demoralizing, it is a wonder that I even got a bachelors degree.” He applauds black students for starting organization to speak out against racism, but he criticizes black educators who choose not to vocally support these groups. Smith says every institution has a duty to address and fix the urban crisis.

pbcoreTitle.title: Reading from his work, Langston Hughes, CA. 1956, Part 1 of 4

pbcoreSubject.subject: African American Civil Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "African American Civil Rights" Categories

pbcoreDescription.description:
Langston Hughes talks about his career as a writer on the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. Hughes was a pivotal literary figure during the Harlem Renaissance. He tells the story of how he became a poet when his eighth grade classmates unanimously voted on him to be the class poet.
He then reads two poems that he wrote in high school.
This is part 1 of 4. Static.

pbcoreSubject.subject: Equal Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Equal Rights" Categories

pbcoreSubject.subject: African American Civil Rights

pbcoreDescription.description: Langston Hughes talks about his career as a writer on the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. He recites a poem called ‘Merry-Go-Round’ that deals with race in a democracy. Hughes then talks about his introduction to jazz music while living in Paris. He goes on to talk about how bebop music influenced his poetry.
This is part 3 of 4. Very loud at start. Heavy static until 0:03:00. Sound is comparatively weak on this side.

pbcoreTitle.title: Reading from his work, Langston Hughes, CA. 1956, Part 4 of 4

pbcoreSubject.subject: African American Civil Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "African American Civil Rights" Categories

pbcoreDescription.description: Langston Hughes talks about his career as a writer on the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. He tells a group of students about what it takes to succeed as a writer. Hughes reads one of his earliest poems, which was written right after he graduated from high school. In closing, he says the contributions of the nation's black people are gradually being recognized, but he says he is bothered by the slow progression of race relations.
This is part 4 of 4. At the beginning of the disc there is a recording of a student test procedure unrelated to the Langston Hughes speech. Hughes starts at 0:02:23.

pbcoreSubject.subject: African American Civil Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "African American Civil Rights" Categories

pbcoreSubject.subject: Equal Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Equal Rights" Categories

pbcoreDescription.description: On the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Washington Post reporter Allen Barth talks about the importance of having an open dialogue on civil liberties and civil rights. He says one of the fundamental aspects of human life is that people are entitled to respect and dignity “by reason of his own individual human personality.” He adds that in a free society, states should allow people to grow based on their own potential.
This is part 1 of 4. Disc is noisy due to embedded dirt. Disc was cleaned but noise still prevalent.

pbcoreTitle.title: Civil Liberties: Your Right to be Different, by Allen Barth, April 26, 1958, Part 3 of 4

pbcoreSubject.subject: Equal Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Equal Rights" Categories

pbcoreDescription.description: On the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Washington Post reporter Allen Barth talks about the importance of having an open dialogue on civil liberties and civil rights. He praises the country for its communal associations where people can freely discuss the issues on their mind. Barth labels the United States as a “pluralistic society” where an array of cultural pursuits are accepted, but he says it can only remain to be that kind of society if all Americans “maintain a tolerance for that kind of variety.”
This is part 3 of 4. Disc is noisy due to embedded dirt. Disc was cleaned but noise still prevalent.

pbcoreSubject.subject: Equal Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Equal Rights" Categories

pbcoreDescription.description: On the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Washington Post reporter Allen Barth talks about the importance of having an open dialogue on civil liberties and civil rights. He says religious intolerance is a menace to the nation, and he urges society to respect the beliefs of other people. As he discusses the freedom of speech and press, he says the press has a duty to warn the public when the government encroaches on constitutional rights.
This is part 2 of 4. Disc is noisy due to embedded dirt. Disc was cleaned but noise still prevalent

pbcoreDescription.description: On the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, chemist Percy L. Julian criticizes how eager Americans are to replace social evils with public candidness, and in doing so, refuse to take steps to guarantee civil rights. He objects to the notion that “we are alright just as we are” by drawing on examples of significant scientific discoveries.

pbcoreSubject.subject: Student Movement
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Student Movement" Categories

pbcoreDescription.description:
On the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, chemist Percy L. Julian says he is optimistic that race relations will get better in the United States. Americans are starting to re-examine their own identities, he says, and making strides towards improving the world around them. “It is this stern self-examination that is causing us to make a beginning towards changing the course of human history,” he says.
After he finishes speaking, Julian takes questions from the audience.

pbcoreIdentifier.identifier: Division of Broadcasting Sound Recordings, Record Series 13/6/5, Tape 133

pbcoreTitle.title: The University and the Urban Challenge, by John Lindsay, April 30, 1968

pbcoreSubject.subject: African American Civil Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "African American Civil Rights" Categories

pbcoreSubject.subject: Economic Justice
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Economic Justice" Categories

pbcoreSubject.subject: National Advisory Committee on Civil Disorders
Equal Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Equal Rights" Categories

pbcoreDescription.description:
At a speech on the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign campus, New York Mayor John Lindsay says peace cannot be imposed in cities by violence. He says to maintain long-term civil order in urban slums, it is critical to persuade youth in those areas to work with government, not against it. Lindsay says teenagers growing up in urban slums carry a stigma that makes them undesirable in the workforce, but building a connection with them may be the secret to re-building America’s cities. To strengthen the nation, Lindsay calls for an end to prejudice and “blind hatred.”
At the end of his speech, Lindsay takes questions from the audience.

pbcoreDescription.description: During a speech on the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, the Rev. Charles Jones talks about the usefulness of sit-ins as a method of improving civil rights. Even though this is a new approach for desegregation, he says this is not a new form of protest. He talks about his involvement with a sit-in started by Chapel Hill High School students. Jones says he learned from the sit-in that the boycott is an effective weapon against segregation because of the value of “the Negro buying power.”
This is part 3 of 4. Static. Loud click 06:23-07:48.

pbcoreDescription.description: During a speech on the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, the Rev. Charles Jones talks about the usefulness of sit-ins as a method of improving civil rights. Even though this is a new approach for desegregation, he says this is not a new form of protest. He talks about his involvement with a sit-in started by Chapel Hill High School students, and how the community responded to the non-violent movement.
This is part 2 of 4. Static.

Charles Jones talks about the usefulness of sit-ins as a method of improving civil rights. Even though this is a new approach for desegregation, he says this is not a new form of protest. Freedom, a panel discussion with Carl Sandburg et al, ca. 1955.

pbcoreSubject.subject: Local Events
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Local Events" Categories

pbcoreDescription.description: First tape of the Bement Centennial discussion. Speaker is Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican from Wisconsin. Begins with talk of Abraham Lincoln and his inspiration of courage, prayer, and devotion to causes greater than oneself. Refers to communist countries as "slave states" and communism as slavery.

Label reads "Bement Centennial Conference 1955. Senator Wiley, Speaker." (Alexander Wiley, Wisconsin)
This is part 1 of 4, followed by 1477A.
First tape of the Bement Centennial Conference which spans many item numbers and includes different speakers.
Very noisy recording - hum, static, loud rumbling, buzz.

Freedom, a panel discussion with Carl Sandburg et al.

pbcoreDescription.description: Part 3 of the Bement Centennial Conference. Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, speaks of the hope that capitalist countries need to provide other countries as a bulwark against communism. Discusses threat to the midwest from Soviet missiles, justifying expansion of the defense budget.

This is part 3 of 4. Label reads "Bement Centennial Conference 1955. Senator Wiley, Speaker."
Follows 1476A and 1477A.
Noisy recording. Noise at ~9:20.

pbcoreDescription.description: Part two of Bement Centennial Conference, with the speaker Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin. Discusses having to co-exist with the Soviet Union because of the threat of a third World War. Talks of the Marshall Plan and other US efforts to rebuild Europe and Japan after World War II.

Label reads "Bement Centennial Conference 1955. Senator Wiley, Speaker."
This is part 2 of 4. Follows 1476A, precedes 1476B.
Noisy still, but better than parts 1&3.

pbcoreDescription.description: Continuation of Bement Centennial Conference with Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin. Begins with a moderated Q&A with questions focused primarily on the threat of communism, a question about foreign aid and assistance, stating that foreign assistance is an investment in American security.
Part 4 of 4, following 1476A, 1477A, and 1476B, of Senator Wiley, R-Wis.

Wind noise and people in background.
Label reads "Bement Centennial Conference 1955. Introduction by Eddy Glennon, Charles Schuman, Speaker," but this is incorrect.

pbcoreDescription.description: Charles Schuman, a native of Sullivan, IL, graduate of the University of Illinois, and the President of the American Farm Bureau Federation, speaks on the role of agriculture in the promotion of freedom. Contrasts America with socialist and communist nations.

Label reads "Bement Centennial Conference 1955. Introduction by Eddy Glennon, Charles Schuman, Speaker."
This is part 1 of 3, followed by 1479A.
Wind noise and people in background.

pbcoreTitle.title: "Freedom," the Bement, IL, Centennial Conference of 1955. Speech by Charles Schmuan, President of the American Farm Bureau Federation. Part 3 of 3.
Freedom, a panel discussion with Carl Sandburg et al, ca. 1955

pbcoreSubject.subject: Local Events
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Local Events" Categories

pbcoreDescription.description: Charles Schuman, a native of Sullivan, IL, graduate of the University of Illinois, and the President of the American Farm Bureau Federation, speaks on the role of agriculture in the promotion of freedom. Contrasts America with socialist and communist nations. Speaks out against crop price supports as a trade-off between more regulation and more state power. Calls socialist countries "slave states." Says that dependence on government for what had been the responsibility of an individual is a step toward socialism and Godlessness.
Part 3 of 3, preceded by 1479A.
Subject is so close to microphone - distorts at times - recorded level is very high.

pbcoreDescription.description: Charles Schuman, a native of Sullivan, IL, graduate of the University of Illinois, and the President of the American Farm Bureau Federation, speaks on the role of agriculture in the promotion of freedom. Contrasts America with socialist and communist nations. Speaks out against crop price supports as a trade-off between more regulation and more state power. Calls socialist countries "slave states."

Label reads "Bement Centennial Conference 1955. Charles Schuman, Speaker."

There's a pause approx. 3/4 into recording. Wind noise and people in background. Subject is so close to microphone - distorts at times - recorded level is very high.

pbcoreDescription.description: Wendell Wilkie, Jr., refers to socialist countries as "slave states," in contrast to what he calls the free nation of the United States. Feels the threat of communism is great partially because communications and transportation has made the world "a smaller place" than it had been in the past. Also says he feels that trade might help the cause of capitalism.

This is part 2 of 3. Label reads "Bement Centennial Conference 1955. Speech by Wendell Wilkie, Jr."
Preceded by 1480A, followed by 1480B
Recording had loud hum. Subject is so close to microphone - distorts at times - recorded level is very high. Tape ends just as Q&A begins.

Freedom, a panel discussion with Carl Sandburg et al, ca. 1955

pbcoreSubject.subject: Local Events
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Local Events" Categories

pbcoreSubject.subject: Equal Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Equal Rights" Categories

pbcoreDescription.description: Wendell Willkie, Jr., discusses the Civil War and the era of Lincoln in comparison to the 1950s and compares the slavery of the pre-Civil War South to what he calls "slavery" under communism. Willkie refers to socialist countries as "slave states," in contrast to what he calls the free nation of the United States. Feels the threat of communism is great partially because communications and transportation has made the world "a smaller place" than it had been in the past. Says the Brown v. Board of Education decision and the censuring of Joseph McCarthy would be looked back upon as historic events.

This is part 1 of 3. Label reads "Bement Centennial Conference 1955. Speech by Wendell Willkie, Jr."
Followed by 1479A
Recording had loud hum. Subject is so close to microphone - distorts at times - recorded level is very high.

pbcoreDescription.description: Wendell Willkie at the 1955 Bement Centennial Conference. Discusses the threat of communism but also the threat of censorship by the likes of Sen. Joseph McCarthy. Also says that international trade can help spread capitalism and calls disarmament a worthy goal of US foreign policy. Most of this segment is made up of a moderated Q&A session, continued from part 2.

Part 3 of Bement Conference talk by Wendell Willkie, Jr.
Preceded by Part 1, 1480A, and Part 2, 1479B.
Subject is so close to microphone - distorts to unintelligibility at times - recorded level is very high.

pbcoreTitle.title: Racial Discrimination in Education, by Edmund Gordon, December 6, 1967
Equalizing the opportunity to Learn, Edmund Gordon, December 6, 1967

pbcoreSubject.subject: School Desegregation
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "School Desegregation" Categories

pbcoreSubject.subject: Equal Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Equal Rights" Categories

pbcoreSubject.subject: African American Civil Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "African American Civil Rights" Categories

pbcoreDescription.description: Psychology professor Edmund Gordon of Yeshiva University talks about equal opportunities for education during a speech at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. He describes how educability and education have changed over the years thanks to various factors such as commerce, religion and technology. Gordon says problems with maintaining social equality in the classroom were more widely discussed with “separate schools.” Yet, he says academic problems have risen with integrated education. Gordon describes how schools and communities can help narrow the achievement gap of students from various racial and socioeconomic backgrounds.

pbcoreDescription.description: Thurgood Marshall speaks of the status of the Civil Rights movement as of 1956. Events mentioned in this part of the talk include attempts to legislate desegregation in Mississippi and the social, legal and financial blockades that opponents put in place. Also discusses the white response to the admission of Autherine Lucy to the University of Alabama.
This is side 2 of 4. Stops abruptly while he is still speaking.

pbcoreDescription.description: Thurgood Marshall speaks of the status of the Civil Rights movement as of 1956. Discussed in this part of the talk are relatively unpublicized instances of segregation in Illinois and the notion that discrimination is not solely relegated to the south. Marshall says that actions to end segregation need to be promoted everywhere in the United States and that the focus on the south negates de facto segregation in all parts of the country.
This is side 4 of 4, following 1650A, 1651A and 1650B.

pbcoreTitle.title: Women and the Years Ahead, Paul A. Miller, November 8, 1967

pbcoreSubject.subject: Economic Justice
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Economic Justice" Categories

pbcoreSubject.subject: Women’s Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Women’s Rights" Categories

pbcoreSubject.subject: Equal Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Equal Rights " Categories

pbcoreDescription.description: As part of a symposium at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Paul A. Miller, Assistant Secretary for Education during the Lyndon Johnson administration, talks about the domestic and occupational stresses put on women. He says governmental policies have helped reduce these pressures by broadening the range of professional options for women. Yet, Miller says society is still hurting by the prevalent belief that women who work are “sure to compromise their own femininity.”

Miller credits women for being a positive influence on his life.

pbcoreDescription.description: During a visit to the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Louis H. Pollack, dean of the Yale Law School, tries to make the case on why it is important in a democracy for academic communities to be socially and politically neutral. Pollack points to several U.S. Supreme Court cases in which “separate, but equal" started to fall apart. He also discusses how the court's definitions governing the political community have strengthened the academic community.

pbcoreTitle.title: Life Patterns in the U.S., Dr. Benjamin Spock, October 16, 1968

pbcoreSubject.subject: Economic Justice
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Economic Justice" Categories

pbcoreSubject.subject: African American Civil Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "African American Civil Rights" Categories

pbcoreDescription.description:
On the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, pediatrician Dr. Benjamin Spock shares his views on issues ranging from war, racial discrimination and poverty. He says the Vietnam War is a violation of international law, and is simply another example of America's imperialistic tendencies. On the issue of racial discrimination, Spock criticizes the notion that people who are discriminated against should be justly to their oppressors. Finally, he says the federal government should provide more assistance to people struggling with health coverage, poverty and education.
Spock concludes by taking questions from the audience.
The Q&A session cuts off shortly after the first question from an audience member.

pbcoreTitle.title: Village Violence and Village Pacification in Vietnam, Ithiel De Sola Pool, February 29, 1968
Edmund James Centennial Lecture, University of Illinois

pbcoreSubject.subject: Civil Unrest
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Civil Unrest" Categories

pbcoreDescription.description: On the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Ithiel De Sola Pool, head of the political science department at MIT, talks about the history of widespread violence in village societies. He points to land disputes, political divisions and differences in the caste system as a few of the reasons for major conflicts. Even though guerilla movements can unite peasants, Pool questions their appeal since it is the peasants who usually lose their lives.

Annual Afro-American History Conference, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign

pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "White Resistance" Categories

pbcoreDescription.description: During the final session of the 3rd Annual Afro-American History Conference at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Robert Zangrando of the American Historical Association reads his paper about how the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP) influenced the Negro protest movement. As a response to the 1908 Springfield, IL race riots, the NAACP was established. The group’s founders were of various racial and socioeconomic statuses, which Zangrando explains is a valid reflection of the progressive era. He details some of the organization’s most notable victories such as housing rights, anti-lynching legislation and integration in the classroom. Zangrando says the NAACP mounted one of the most successful protest movements in the country while following the guidelines of community action “dominated by the white majority.” However, he says many black militants during the 1960s shifted away from the diplomatic teachings of W.E.B. DuBois and focused their attention on Franz Fanon, a social scientist with a more violent tone.

pbcoreTitle.title: The Media and That War, Gene Graham, October 11, 1968

pbcoreSubject.subject: Local Events
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Local Events " Categories

pbcoreDescription.description: Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist Gene Graham speaks at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign about the media coverage during wartime. He says television, with its emotional impact, has given rise to the age of demonstrations. While Graham credits television news for garnering more of an interest in the Vietnam War, he says its coverage has been poor because facts are often distorted for entertainment value.

pbcoreTitle.title: The Escalation of Violence, with Mary Ann Ferber and Norton Long, October 25, 1968

pbcoreSubject.subject: Civil Unrest
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Civil Unrest" Categories

pbcoreSubject.subject: Equal Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Equal Rights" Categories

pbcoreDescription.description: Norton Long, a political science professor at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, talks about the transition of going from a society with civil unrest and violence to one with peace and order. He says the forces that are meant to keep people “from letting loose” in a society, like in the black community, can be disruptive and oppressive. In order to successfully govern, leaders need support from many groups. “Anybody who wants order in the United States must want effective organization and power for blacks in the United States,” he says. To prevent the escalation of violence, he says it is also up to educators to give people a sense of purpose.

pbcoreDescription.description: On the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, playwright and novelist James Baldwin discusses how in America, law and order only applies to people with power. He says whites expect blacks to sacrifice so much, like going to war, but show little in return. “You bring him back and pat him on the head, put him back in the ghetto and say, ‘Be nice. It’ll be better tomorrow,’” Baldwin declares. “Whose tomorrow? And for how long?” It is up to black people, he concludes, to stand up against oppression.

pbcoreDescription.description:
Television producer Wardell Gaynor speaks at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign about why it is necessary for the black artist to be an activist. He says success does not guarantee absolute freedom.
After his speech, Gaynor appears on the WILL Radio program, Open End. He talks with student Joseph Tankiesling, author Ellis Pekay and art professor John Schuller.

pbcoreDescription.description: During a speech on the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, civil rights activist Beatrice Young argues that the cultural contributions of African Americans should be taught in the classroom. Young says the public needs new insight into the conditions of slavery, and suggests that an ideal course must be based in the slave era from the perspective of the enslaved. Young adds that another major point in the cultural history of blacks is the migration of African Americans from the rural South to the urban North. She also provides an overview of some of the major cultural contributions by African American artists.

Student Disorders: University Reform and Our Legal System, Michael J. Severn, April 25, 1969

pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Voting Rights" Categories

pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "African American Civil Rights" Categories

pbcoreDescription.description:
On the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, U.S. Senator Charles Percy (R-IL) talks about efforts to improve his state’s schools. Percy says he wants to see more federal revenue streams going towards Illinois’ schools. He adds that on the issue of student unrest, educators should take more time to listen to the concerns of students.
Then, Columbia University professor Michael J. Severn then points to some of the problems with the county’s higher education system. He says students are often disappointed with the quality of the course material and instructors. Severn says universities need to stop thinking of students as customers, and start giving them more of a voice in the daily affairs impacting the campus.

pbcoreDescription.description:
Literary editor Hoyt Fuller talks about the status of black literature in America during a speech on the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. He says there is a revolution among black writers who are straying away from traditional Western literature, and dispelling images and myths degrading to black people.
Then, scholar Harold Cruse says modern black writers need a strong perspective of their “cultural ingredients” because they are “known to be very expressive on all levels of creativity.” To better equip students with the ability to synthesize past events and make them relevant today, Cruse proposes a black studies program where the works by older black writers are compared with contemporary ones.

pbcoreDescription.description: On the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, activist John Froines and attorney William Kunstler talk abut the infamous “Chicago Seven” case in which several defendants, including Froines, were put on trial for inciting a violent riot during the 1968 Democratic National Convention. Kunstler successfully defended the protesters who were put on trial. Kunstler says in the midst of a social revolution, “there is apparently not going to be an ear to listen to protest, or if the ear is listening it is an ear which is clogged.” He encourages people to take their protest to another level if no one is listening.
Contains language some may consider obscene

pbcoreDescription.description: On the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, William Robinson, former director of the Cook County Department of Public Aid, talks about how the law has let poor people down. Past court rulings have kept the nation's caste/class system alive, and he says the poor have traditionally viewed the justice system as uncongenial to their interests. Yet, Robinson concludes there is an emerging trust in the law to extend economic and civil rights to the disadvantaged.

pbcoreDescription.description: During a visit to the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, author Julius Lester says until there is a definition of what "blackness" means, there will be a “vacuum of leadership” in the black movement. He says more should be expected from the movement's leaders beyond the impassioned and fiery rhetoric. “We feel the same vibrations, but social movements don’t move on vibrations,” Lester states. “Social movements move by hard work toward very clear, very well-defined goals.” At the university level, Lester says black studies programs should prepare students to use the knowledge they gain in the classroom to strengthen the push for civil rights.

pbcoreDescription.description: At the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, actress Val Gray Ward says the black activist has a creative and practical side, and she explains that blackness in an artist “will express itself consciously and unconsciously.” She encourages black artists to include themes in their work dealing with the black and white condition. “If the artist is to capture the critical movement among black people,” Ward says. “He must be apart of it.” She concludes that the black artist of the future will be a social, political and cultural figure basing all aspects of “his life into a perfect harmony.”

pbcoreDescription.description:
Kermit Coleman, head of the ACLU's ghetto project in Chicago, talks on the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign about how certain rights guaranteed to all Americans are limited in the black community. Some of these rights include letting non-violent groups assemble, casting an impartial jury during a trial and making voter registration accessible. He connects the plight facing the black community to the interpretation and enforcement of laws.
After his speech, Coleman talks to law students David Addison and Doris Waylen on the WILL radio program, Open End.

pbcoreDescription.description: On the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, economist Gunnar Myrdal, recipient of the Nobel Peace Prize for Economic Sciences, talks about some of the central problems involving race during the 20th century. He says the only thing wrong with black people is the racism that they have endured by white people. “The Negroes are just ordinary Americans, ordinary human beings," he says. Myrdal describes how he correctly predicted when Americans would see a decline in racism. He also explains how the civil rights movement became such a strong community force against white resistance.

pbcoreDescription.description:
On the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, economist Gunnar Myrdal, recipient of the Nobel Peace Prize for Economic Sciences, talks about some of the central problems involving race during the 20th century. Myrdal assesses the federal government's efforts to improve the economy, an issue he says impacts many African Americans. He says in order to reduce discrimination against black people, poverty and unemployment levels need to be lowered.
After his speech, Myrdal takes questions from the audience.

pbcoreDescription.description: On the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, economist Gunnar Myrdal, recipient of the Nobel Peace Prize for Economic Sciences, continues to take questions from the audience. He is talking about some of the central problems involving race in America during the twentieth century. He says people who are uneducated about a society’s language and culture are more likely to struggle in that region's labor market.

pbcoreTitle.title: Is the South That Bad? by Hodding Carter and Coleman Griffith, March 2, 1949

pbcoreSubject.subject: African American Civil Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Program "African American Civil Rights" List

pbcoreDescription.description: Discussion about race relations in the south toward the end of the 1940s. Carter, a native of Louisiana, says that there is not one single south, and that to call it so is an over-simplification. Carter looks at progress made by blacks in the south and calls it a place of contradictions but also of hope.
This is side 1 of 4, preceding items 2597A, 2596B and 2597B.
There is a skip approx. 09:20 into this side.

pbcoreIdentifier.identifier: Division of Broadcasting Sound Recordings, Record Series 13/6/5, Disk 2596B

pbcoreTitle.title: Is the South That Bad? by Hodding Carter and Coleman Griffith, March 2, 1949

pbcoreSubject.subject: African American Civil Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Program "African American Civil Rights" List

pbcoreDescription.description: Discussion about race relations in the south toward the end of the 1940s. Carter, a native of the Louisiana, says that there is not one single south, and that to call it so is an over-simplification. Carter looks at progress made by blacks in the south and calls it a place of contradictions but also of hope. Carter questions actual civil rights legislation and says that economic and social plans need to be made that would eradicate the root causes of racism rather than forcing desegregation on the south. Makes a case that there is a background to Southern history that needs to be considered before any real change can take place.
This is side 3 of 4, following 2596A and 2597A

pbcoreDescription.description: Discussion about race relations in the south toward the end of the 1940s. Carter, a native of Louisiana, says that there is not one single south, and that to call it so is an over-simplification. Carter looks at progress made by blacks in the south and calls it a place of contradictions but also of hope. Carter questions actual civil rights legislation and says that economic and social plans need to be made that would eradicate the root causes of racism rather than forcing desegregation on the south. Makes a case that there is a background to Southern history that needs to be considered before any real change can take place. Also says that the "problem" of the south is that of the entire country.
This is side 4 of 4, following 2596A, 2597A and 2596B.
Slight surface noise.

pbcoreDescription.description: Robert G. Clark, who was elected to the Mississippi House of Representatives in 1968, speaks on the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. Clark proposes the development of an economic stabilization program to ease the financial burdens in urban slums across the country. He attributes his state’s critical poverty level to poor economic decisions with employment and education. “When we say the state of Mississippi, we think this applies to the South in general,” says Clarks. He explains that if the South’s economic conditions improve, then that will have a ripple effect across the nation.

pbcoreTitle.title: Law, Justice or Oppression? Marshall Rattner, April 24, 1969

pbcoreSubject.subject: Court Rulings
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Court Rulings" Categories

pbcoreSubject.subject: Economic Justice
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Economic Justice" Categories

pbcoreSubject.subject: Equal Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Equal Rights" Categories

pbcoreDescription.description:
On the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, attorney Marshall Rattner provides an overview of cases involving oppression in the housing market. He says among the problems, the federal government creates a false market by not guaranteeing mortgages in “changing neighborhoods,” where many blacks live. This “black tax,” he says, makes housing more expensive. Rattner is challenging a statute that protects landlords from an array of tenant abuses, such as overcharging people for rent and giving tenants an inadequate notice prior to an eviction. He says he hopes reforms to these violations and others will give tenants more of a voice, possibly in the form of a coalition.
After Rattner finishes his speech, he takes questions from the audience.

pbcoreDescription.description:
On the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Columbia Law School professor Michael I. Sovern says twice as many blacks are unemployed in the United States compared to whites. While the law does offer protections against racially motivated hiring practices, Sovern says more could be done to provide blacks with the training they need to move up in the workforce.
After his lecture, Sovern takes questions from the audience.

pbcoreDescription.description: During a visit to the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, William Grier, who heads the psychiatry department at Meharry Medical College, talks about the black identity. He says black kids grow up with the notion that they are inferior to whites because of negative racial attitudes around them. Yet, if a child growing up with these values understands his or her importance in society, then Grier expresses hope that they will recognize the problems of race in America. “We’re determined to rid this nation of bigotry and racial hatred,” he says.

pbcoreTitle.title: Crisis of Identity and Education in the Black Struggle, P. Chike Onwuachi, April 27, 1970

pbcoreSubject.subject: Civil Unrest
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Civil Unrest" Categories

pbcoreSubject.subject: African American Civil Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "African American Civil Rights" Categories

pbcoreSubject.subject: Equal Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Equal Rights" Categories

pbcoreDescription.description: On the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, P. Chike Onwuachi, director of the African-Caribbean Studies Center at Fisk University, talks about the black power movement and black identity. Contrary to what some people may think, he says black power does not represent violence or racism, but rather a form of self-defense and unity. He also objects to the term “Negro” because he says it carries a literal meaning of pure race and a symbolic one describing a dead person. There are very few pure-raced people, he says, and “we’re not dead.” He adds: “When we talk about our blackness, we’re talking about a new humanism.”

pbcoreTitle.title: Education and the Black Community, Charles G. Hurst, Jr., President, Malcolm X College, Chicago, October 28, 1970
Black Culture Lecture Series

pbcoreSubject.subject: African American Civil Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "African American Civil Rights" Categories

pbcoreSubject.subject: Equal Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Equal Rights" Categories

pbcoreDescription.description:
Charles G. Hurst, Jr., president of Malcolm X College in Chicago, speaks on the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign about the task of educating America’s black people. He says it is a difficult task in part because of the belief that freedom can only be gained by prayer. “I think we know now that freedom is something that you don’t just get by praying,” he says. In order to eliminate racism, Hurst says all people need to be educated about the problems surrounding race, rather than rely on a select few enlightened individuals to change the world.
After his speech, Hurst is interviewed on WILL Radio about what he thinks should be done to reform public education.

pbcoreDescription.description: During a visit to the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Governor Otto Kerner (D-IL) talks about a federal report that looks at the causes of the 1967 race riots. The findings of the report were compiled by an 11-member commission chaired by Kerner. President Lyndon B. Johnson appointed the commission. Kerner states the riots were not part of any organized plan, but grew from a mixture of racial and economic tensions from within the black community. He says many of those who participated in the demonstrations were young African Americans who were anxious to get the same opportunities as whites, like a proper education. Sticking to the status quo is not a solution, and he suggests several reforms to control the country’s widening racial gap.

pbcoreTitle.title: Urban Problems Debate, with Sam Yorty and Adam Clayton Powell, November 20, 1968

pbcoreSubject.subject: African American Civil Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "African American Civil Rights" Categories

pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Local Events" Categories

pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Student Movement" Categories

pbcoreDescription.description:
On the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Los Angeles Mayor Sam Yorty and New York Congressman Adam Clayton Powell address urban problems. On the issue of urban renewal projects, Yorty says he opposes measures that uproot people from their homes. He also talks about his efforts to integrate city government, and cautions people from looking down on law enforcement because of a few bad incidences of racial tension. Police training should go a step further, says Powell, by evaluating prospective officers on their abilities to work with people of various backgrounds. Powell also talks about the role of young people in organizing a coalition to bring forth many of the nation’s racial and social problems. “Black is not the color of your skin, but the way you think,” he says. Powell also addresses the financial strain that the Vietnam War is putting on the nation’s cities.
After the debate, Yorty and Powell take questions from the audience.
Contains language some may consider obscene.

This entry was originally titled:
'Environment of Minority Groups: Environmental Hazards Experience by the United Farm Workers; and the Native American and Pollution, Edward Reddeck; Eliseo Medina, Eastern Coordinator of the United Farm Works, part of Environmental Crisis Week Program, April 22, 1970'
This title noted only two speakers when there's actually three. I think the third speaker is Sydney Beane, a documentary filmmaker and American Indian civil rights activist, but I'm not 100% sure. The intro to his last name sounds like 'MEE-n'
Also, I can't find any information on Edward Reddeck. Don't know if his named is spelled wrong, or if there is simply no information about him online. The audio doesn't include an intro for Mr. Reddeck.

Conference on Invasion of Privacy

pbcoreDescription.description: On the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, political activist Michael Harrington argues that many people do not benefit from welfare because of the invasion of privacy that accompanies the federal assistance program. He says the lack of privacy has adverse effects on the mental and physical health of the poor. As a “moralistic society,” he says the poor are held to a higher standard when they try to benefit from the program. As one solution to the issue, Harrington says a poor person should not be required to surrender certain rights in order to get assistance.

pbcoreDescription.description:
Elsie Easley, local welfare activist, speaks on the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign about efforts to protect the rights of welfare recipients.
Then, poverty rights activist George Wiley describes some of the problems with the federal government’s welfare assistance program. He says it does not meet the needs of poor people. In fact, Wiley contends that the system is designed to screen out anyone who has “any conceivable means of supporting himself.”

pbcoreDescription.description: Journalist Burleigh Hines talks about the black identity on the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. He says the “black man will never be able to escape his identity,” and that it is hypocritical of whites to think black people are pushing too hard for prominence. “It is incredibly naïve to think that black people would be capable of taking this bull they’ve taken for more than 300 years, and accept it with just a song and a dance,” says Hines. Lack of knowledge about black history has contributed to racism, which is why Hines says black history should be taught to all Americans.

pbcoreDescription.description: On the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, comedian Dick Gregory says young people have inherited social problems from “old fools” that must now be solved. He says a major tension point between blacks and whites is a misunderstanding about why blacks are reacting to racism: “Any old fool knows this is a racist county that oppresses folks.” He says the county has been separate for too long, and he urges black people to embrace their heritage.

pbcoreDescription.description: Journalist L.F. Palmer speaks on the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign about the future of the black movement. He says students are strong leaders, and could learn a lot from those who have shaped the movement. “This black revolution found its way through the chambers of fear and uncertainty to the threshold of actual realization that black people must not only acquire power, but maintain power,” says Palmer. He says the 1970s movement will “facilitate the transition from one level of struggle to the next highest step toward freedom.”

pbcoreTitle.title: The Assault on Privacy, Arthur Miller, February 25, 1971

pbcoreSubject.subject: Court Rulings
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Court Rulings" Categories

pbcoreSubject.subject: Equal Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Equal Rights" Categories

pbcoreDescription.description:
On the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Arthur Miller, one of the nation's foremost authorities on the legal question of privacy, talks to a group of students. Miller says the government is watching the public more now than ever before thanks to technology. He says regular activities like purchases or job interviews are often recorded in a computer leaving distinctive electronic tracks “that can tell a great deal about us.” He explains that the government keeps tabs on people who pose a serious threat, often at the expense of other people's liberties. Miller doubts that privacy can be handled in the courts, which is why he encourages Congress to draft legislation that can balance data collection and individual privacy. Miller also hopes an agency will be established to monitor information collected by the federal government and private sectors.
After he finishes his speech, Miller takes questions from the audience.

pbcoreTitle.title: Black Art Today, Charles White, April 26, 1971

pbcoreSubject.subject: African American Civil Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "African American Civil Rights" Categories

pbcoreDescription.description:
On the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Charles White talks about the importance of art as a form of expression. As a black kid from the slums of Chicago, White says he was able to identify his own self-worth through art: “It helped me take myself away from the degradation from that environment.”
During the course of his lecture at the U of I, White talks about his artwork.

pbcoreTitle.title: The Language of Blackness, Orlando Taylor, April 21, 1971

pbcoreSubject.subject: Equal Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Equal Rights" Categories

pbcoreSubject.subject: School Desegregation
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "School Desegregation" Categories

pbcoreDescription.description: At the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, speech pathologist Orlando Taylor says more people are talking about what it means to be black because there are more black students in public schools, and the linguistic differences between whites and blacks in the classroom are much more noticeable. Taylor says some people wonder if many of the nation’s educational problems, especially in urban settings, are related to these disparities. There is no evidence, he explains, to support such a claim. Historically, blacks have been viewed as linguistically deprived, a departure from the southern white speech models. When black people came to the U.S., he argues that they arrived with a rich linguistic history, which included exposure and creolization to languages from Europe and West Africa. “The language of blackness is very normal,” he says. “All people have a culture, and all people have a language to express ideas of that culture.”

pbcoreSubject.subject: African American Civil Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "African American Civil Rights " Categories

pbcoreSubject.subject: Student Movement

pbcoreDescription.description:
On the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, attorney David Addison talks about the needs in the black community “where political and psychological unity takes place.” He says a problem within the black movement is the lack of communication and knowledge about American history. He says unless we “get it together” black people will lose the expertise to build a community and survive in a technological society.
After his speech, Addison takes questions from the audience.

pbcoreDescription.description: On the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Miriam Shelden, Chair of the Chancellor's Committee on the Status of Women, says women should be full partners at universities, like the U of I. Shelden dismisses the notion that the civil rights and women’s rights movements are an “even or proposition” because members of both movements are trying to share the power largely located in white male communities. She provides examples of how women are being mistreated in the workplace, and concludes that attitudes towards women have to change.

pbcoreDescription.description: Clarence Shelley, director of the Special Educational Opportunities Program, talks to students at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign about how the level of elitism at universities enfeebles student and faculty success. Shelley says there are major differences of opinion among various political and social groups about the goals of higher education. He says the status quo is not acceptable, and diversifying institutions of higher education will help wipe away the belief that all students should be the same.

pbcoreDescription.description: Civil right activist Jesse Jackson talks to a crowd on the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign about the political economy, a term used to describe decisions made by the executive branch of the United States without Congressional approval. These decisions can have major economic implications, especially on black people. Jackson says in a country where power gets privilege, hard work does not mean economic success. In order to overcome the economic problems facing blacks, Jackson encourages the black community to become more aware of how the political economy is restrictive. “You can’t teach what you don’t know,” he proclaims.

pbcoreDescription.description: During a speech on the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign campus, civil rights leader Leon Sullivan calls on black people to use their brains to achieve economic equality. “Integration without preparation is frustrating,” says Sullivan. He describes how he has trained blacks to be more desirable in the workforce. However, before they can claim economic success, he says they must recognize their black pride by dismissing the notion that they are inferior to white people.

pbcoreDescription.description: Lecture given at the University of Illinois, 1972. The Black nationalist approach to civil rights, the problem of access to education and black economic self-determination are discussed. Compares a measurement of economic GDP of African-Americans against the total GDP of other countries. Also says that a legacy of differentiation between sub-classes of plantation slaves continues to exist in the 1970s and that there is a conflict between Nationalists and assimilationists. Says the first goal of Black nationalism is community control.
Contains language suitable for mature audiences.

pbcoreSubject.subject: African American Civil Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "African American Civil Rights" Categories

pbcoreDescription.description: Taylor Oline on the role of Christianity in propagating racism; focuses primarily on the northern United States prior to the Civil War, saying that blacks in the "free" north suffered as much as blacks did in the slave states of the south, and that this segregation and racism was promoted and encouraged by Christian churches. Also looks at the role of different Christian churches, especially the Anglican Church, in colonization and slavery.

She begins talking of sociological studies that find problems within African-American families while ignoring larger racist social factors, as well as assume a bias toward white middle-class standards.

pbcoreSubject.subject: Women's Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Women's Rights" Categories

pbcoreSubject.subject: Economic Justice
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Economic Justice" Categories

pbcoreDescription.description: Talk given at the University of Illinois YMCA, 1972. Covers possible future changes in the roles for women in American life. He looks at the lives of American women in the years following World War II that focused primarily on raising children and how that contrasted with the 1960s, when the children of the Baby Boom generation became college students. He says that the early Baby Boom years gave women a clear sense of purpose that was reinforced by media images of the family, and that by the 1960s, there was more of an emphasis on employment outside the home, a trend he says would continue into the 1970s and beyond.

Discusses segregation in economics and employment by race or gender and differences in child-rearing roles of men and women. Also talks about the relationship between masculinity and the military, especially with regard to Vietnam. Margaret Sloan discusses discrimination from a race and gender perspective.
Contains language suitable for mature audiences.

pbcoreTitle.title: Black Identity: The Search Through Individual Political Involvement, by Kenneth Cockrel, February 28, 1973

pbcoreSubject.subject: African American Civil Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "African American Civil Rights" Categories

pbcoreSubject.subject: National Association for the Advancement of Colored People
Workers Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Workers Rights" Categories

pbcoreSubject.subject: White Resistance
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "White Resistance" Categories

pbcoreSubject.subject: Civil Unrest
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Civil Unrest" Categories

pbcoreDescription.description:
On the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Kenneth Cockrel, a member of the Detroit city council, talks about identity as it relates to the black struggle movement. He says the actions by black people who resisted economic, social and racial oppression should be closely studied. These actions, which he says are part of the black identity, have helped obliterate imperialistic tendencies. As he reflects on the black power movement, Cockrel says organizations should focus more attention on the plight of all black people rather than the individual identity of a few leaders. He concludes that members of the movement should create an independent political organization to mobilize their message.
After his speech, Cockrel takes questions from the audience.
Concluding Q&A ends abruptly.

pbcoreDescription.description: On the campus of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Swedish educationist Torsten Husén says removing social barriers in education could lead to a more democratic society. He says objective indicators, like achievement exams, seem to be the “self-evident selection criterion to replace social class, economic background and personal connections.” However, he concludes by saying that education reforms cannot serve as a substitute for social reforms.
Loud hum in original tape which intensifies in second half. Momentary drop out in concluding remarks.

pbcoreDescription.description: Jesse Jackson discusses the effects of segregation as it applies to urban areas in which African Americans live but lack access to political and economic self-determination. He also speaks of the psychological effects of racism in this manner. Jackson uses the term "colonization" in which to tie European colonization of Africa to the manner in which white power brokers control the economic and political power in urban areas where they do not live.
Recording begins and ends abruptly. Audio levels very loud at times.

pbcoreTitle.title: The Changing Status of Women, Betty Friedan, et al, World Affairs Conference, Quad Cities, March 30 and 31, 1973

pbcoreSubject.subject: Economic Justice
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Economic Justice" Categories

pbcoreSubject.subject: Women's Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Women's Rights" Categories

pbcoreSubject.subject: Equal Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Equal Rights" Categories

pbcoreDescription.description:
Betty Friedan and others speak about the changing role of women from the 1960s into the 1970s. The speakers discuss changing gender roles and the form of the American family and gender relations, touching on sexuality, divorce and violence. Also discuss changes in employment and future economic possibilities for for women and expanding political rights for women throughout the world.
Conservative speaker Midge Decter touches on the same subjects from a conservative point of view, criticizing what she calls "Women's Lib" as the complaints of a privileged class.

Betty Friedan speaks until about 37:00, and then a second unnamed speaker begins.
Second speaker ends at ~56:00 and a third unnamed speaker begins.
Fourth speaker, Midge Decter, begins at ~80:00 after a 5-minute introduction by a male speaker.
This recording may have been recorded over two days, although the dates of each talk and exactly when each talk was recorded is not clear on the recording.
Tape begins abruptly. Recording has loud hum and sounds to be slightly fast. Very poorly recorded.

pbcoreTitle.title: The Changing Status of Women, Betty Friedan, et al, World Affairs Conference, Quad Cities, March 30 and 31, 1973, Part Three

pbcoreSubject.subject: Women’s Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Women’s Rights" Categories

pbcoreDescription.description:
Side One contains a panel discussion that begins with the subject of the roles of China and Russia in Vietnam and President Nixon's visit to China. Discusses status of Taiwan and conditions in Bangladesh. Also discusses the relationship between China, Russia and other Asian nations as well as what were then Western and Eastern Europe.
Side Two, beginning at approximately 60:00, contains a speech by the keynote speaker James Reston. He discusses China, the Nixon visit, his relationship with Nixon and Henry Kissinger. Subjects include the Chinese Communist government, the leadership under Chairman Mao, Chinese-American relations, Chinese-Soviet relations, the social lives of average Chinese citizens, birth control, the lives of women in China, and the overall status of China in the early 1970s.

Listed as "The Changing Status of Women, Betty Friedan, et al, World Affairs Conference, Quad Cities, March 30 and 31, 1973, Part Three." However, this is not the topic of this conversation. It does appear to be part of the World Affairs Conference, but this conversation focuses on Asia.
The first part is a panel discussion, but the name of only one panelist is clear, and that is Leo Gruliow; others' last names are Yu and Shankar.
Keynote speaker James Reston begins at ~60:00.
Side 1 ends abruptly during applause at approximately 59:00. Side 2 contains Q&A. Tape runs out before conclusion. Q&A begins at ~113:00.

pbcoreIdentifier.identifier: Division of Broadcasting Sound Recordings, Record Series 13/6/5, Tape 419

pbcoreTitle.title: America's Emphasis is Wrong, Martin Luther King, Sr., Krannert Great Hall, April 12, 1975

pbcoreSubject.subject: African American Civil Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Program "African American Civil Rights" List

pbcoreDescription.description: Martin Luther King, Sr., speaks about the role of religion in the Civil Rights struggle. Begins with a refusal to feel hatred for the assassin of his son Martin Luther King, Jr., as well as the assassin of his wife Alberta Williams King, who was murdered in 1974. King says that the American emphasis on race and gender is a "misplaced emphasis" and that individuals need to be considered on their own merit. Says that all people are children of God and that race and gender are not relevant as all people need to live by basic religious principles. In the Q&A he discusses nonviolence which he says were taught to him by his son.
Beginning of talk at 6:00 after introductions. Talk ends at 36:00 and Q&A begins.
Audio levels vary from very quiet to very loud. Questions during Q&A are inaudible.

pbcoreTitle.title: Andromeda 21: Blackness and the Harlem Renaissance, with Charles Davis and Hank Parker, 1971
Andromeda 21

pbcoreSubject.subject: African American Civil Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "African American Civil Rights" Categories

pbcoreSubject.subject: Local Events
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Local Events" Categories

pbcoreDescription.description: Discussion of the Harlem Renaissance in the 1920s and 1930s. Delves into the idea that the Harlem Renaissance was one of the first times that African-Americans initiated their own art forms and investigated the relationship between African-Americans and their African roots. Raises the idea that the Harlem Renaissance provided African-Americans with a positive self-image and that the work of African-Americans that came out of the Harlem Renaissance complemented the wider American culture with unique art forms.
Good clear sound. Studio recording.

pbcoreDescription.description: Burleigh Hines, reporter with WBBM Radio in Chicago, discusses the struggle for identity within African-American culture. Discusses what he sees as the failures of the militant black power movement and the tension between black militants and the black middle class, the struggle of the black middle class in urban centers and the troubles within public housing developments.

pbcoreTitle.title: Andromeda 21: "Discussion of Black Music," with Hank Parker and Robert Ray, May 10, 1971
Andromeda 21

pbcoreSubject.subject: African American Civil Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Program "African American Civil Rights" List

pbcoreDescription.description: Robert Ray, Director of the Black Chorus at the University of Illinois, discusses the role of music in African-American culture. Ray says that in the era of slavery and through the 20th century the only place in which African-Americans felt free was in Black Churches, where spirituals allowed an emotional release. Also discusses what he sees as differences between Black music and white music.
Good clear sound. Studio recording.

pbcoreTitle.title: Andromeda 21: "Discussion of Black Music," with Hank Parker and Robert Ray, May 17, 1971
Andromeda 21

pbcoreSubject.subject: African American Civil Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Program "African American Civil Rights" List

pbcoreDescription.description: University of Illinois Black Choir Director Robert Ray discusses the role of music in African-American culture. Begins with a discussion of religious chants, the earliest forms of African music, that he finds to be more prevalent in rural churches than urban churches. Also discusses hymns and the differences between hymns sung in white churches and hymns in black churches. Talks about the social role of the black church.
Studio recording starts abruptly. Good clear sound. A second-week continuation of 449T.

pbcoreTitle.title: Andromeda 21: On Being a Black Artist, with Hank Parker and Charles White, 1971
Andromeda 21

pbcoreSubject.subject: African American Civil Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Program "African American Civil Rights" List

pbcoreDescription.description: Artist Charles White discusses the role of art in African American culture, beginning with the Harlem Renaissance and continuing into the 1970s, an era in which he sees art as more political than that of the Harlem Renaissance had been. Also discusses the role of his African-American identity in his work and the influence of literature, such as that of Langston Hughes and Richard Wright, in his visual work, as well as his view of the relationship of form and content in art.
Studio recording. Good clear sound.

pbcoreTitle.title: Andromeda 21: Working in the Inner City, with Raymond Brodie, Eddie Harris, and Hank Parker, 1971
Andromeda 21

pbcoreSubject.subject: African American Civil Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Program "African American Civil Rights" List

pbcoreDescription.description: The interviewees are the founders of the Institute for Achievement and Motivation, an inner-city Chicago group that aimed to help change mental attitudes in order to solve social problems. The interviewees aim to increase self-esteem among African-American youth. Discussion of the problem of self-image of African-Americans as first a source of labor for colonial powers and then as consumers within the dominant American culture. Moves into specific recommendations for changing self-perception and developing and achieving goals.
Good clear sound. Slightly low levels. Studio recording.

pbcoreSubject.subject: African American Civil Rights

pbcoreDescription.description: Dick Gregory discusses racism in American culture, starting with bias in the media. Mentions a fear of an American dictatorship aided by the FBI and the press. Talks of the difference between "emancipation" and "liberation" and problems and fallacies of the American education system.
Studio recording. Good clear sound. Content same as 448T, but this one is lacking opening/closing music, credits, and pre-recorded intro.

pbcoreTitle.title: Andromeda 21: Discussion of Black lifestyle and music, 1971
Andromeda 21

pbcoreSubject.subject: African American Civil Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Program "African American Civil Rights" List

pbcoreDescription.description:
Robert Ray, Director of the Black Chorus at the University of Illinois, discusses the role of music in African-American culture. Ray says that in the era of slavery and through the 20th century the only place in which African-Americans felt free was in Black Churches, where spirituals allowed an emotional release. Also discusses what he sees as differences between Black music and white music.
In the second half, Ray discusses the role of music in African-American culture. Begins with a discussion of religious chants, the earliest forms of African music, that he finds to be more prevalent in rural churches than urban churches. Also discusses hymns and the differences between hymns sung in white churches and hymns in black churches. Talks about the social role of the black church.
This is the interview portion of 449T and 450T without the opening/closing music and pre-recorded intro or the musical performances of the Black Choir.
Recording ends abruptly.

pbcoreDescription.description:
A group of panelists on the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign campus talk about some of the challenges facing black students in the nation’s public schools. The panelists are involved in the public school system in Champaign, IL. Columbia Elementary School Principal Jim Casey provides a historical overview of efforts to strengthen education for blacks. “The trouble ends with us as parents,” comments Roberta Turner, a parent aid for Garden Hills Elementary School. By simply calling on more participation, education will not improve overnight, says panelist John Johnson. Johnson says the country’s attitude towards blacks needs to change.
After the speakers finish, they take questions from the audience.
Recording ends abruptly.

pbcoreTitle.title: Black and Proud, January 27, 1969
African-American Life in Central Illinois

pbcoreSubject.subject: African American Civil Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "African American Civil Rights" Categories

pbcoreSubject.subject: Workers Rights
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "Workers Rights " Categories

pbcoreSubject.subject: School Desegregation
pbcoreSubject.subjectAuthorityUsed: American Archive Civil Rights "School Desegregation " Categories

pbcoreDescription.description: "Black and Proud" explores the black community’s growing awareness among black residents of Central Illinois of their heritage and contributions to American society. Homemaker Eunice Patterson of Urbana demonstrates her method of cooking soul food. She whips up collard greens, chitlins, sweet potato pie, cornbread and heavenly hash. Host Harold Bradley then talks with two professors at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign about the influence of art and music as a form of self-expression for black people. Then, a University of Illinois student group performs African dance. Later on in the program, a U of I student participate in an Afro-American fashion show. In one of several discussion segments, the founders of The Black Vanguard, a black newspaper in Danville, Illinois, talk about why they began publishing in April 1968.

What is Soul food? The is one of the questions to be answered on "Black and Proud," an hour-long special program about Black culture in East Central Illinois. The program will be broadcast at 9 p.m. Monday, January 27th. The word "soul has a special meaning in the Black community. It becomes an adjective that gives its noun a certain blackness. Soul music, soul brothers, and soul food, all refer to "black things." "Black and Proud" explores these special cultural attributes and the Black community's growing awareness of its own heritage and its contributions to American society.
